questions.text: A 74-year-old man was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder. Which of the following is the most likely risk factor for this type of bladder cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) History of schistosomiasis.

 

Explanation:

 

Histologic Type of Bladder Carcinoma

Risk Factors

Transitional cell carcinoma (>97%)
  • Smoking
  • Occupational exposure (aromatic hydrocarbons):
    • Rubber, paint and dyes, gas and tar industries
    • Hairdressers, plumbers, and painters (Option C)
  • Environmental carcinogens: Arsenic in drinking water
  • Schistosomiasis (SCC >> transitional cell Ca)
  • Drugs: Phenacetin, Cyclophosphamide (Option D)
  • Pelvic radiotherapy

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (1-7%)
  • Schistosomiasis (Option A)
  • Secondary to chronic infections:
  • Indwelling catheter
  • Bladder stone
  • Recurrent infections

Adenocarcinoma (2%)
  • Urachus
  • Augmentation enterocystoplasty (Option B)
  • Bladder exstrophy repair

questions.text: A patient who had undergone cystectomy and urinary diversion with an ileal conduit after being diagnosed with muscle-invasive bladder cancer comes for follow-up. His blood investigations revealed an electrolyte imbalance. Which of the following is not a possible imbalance in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hyponatremia

 

Explanation:

  • The electrolyte imbalance that does not occur in the case of urinary diversion with an ileal conduit is hyponatremia.
  • Sodium is absorbed via trans-cellular and paracellular routes in the ileum and the colon. In the ileum, the sodium loss is not clinically significant and hence hyponatremia does not occur.

Electrolyte Imbalances in Metabolic Acidosis
  • Hypokalemia (Option A): Low potassium levels due to intestinal losses and renal wasting.
  • Hypocalcemia (Option C): Low calcium levels due to renal wasting and bone demineralization.
  • Hypomagnesemia (Option D): Low magnesium levels due to renal wasting.

questions.text: A new mother comes to the outpatient department with her neonate as she notices intermittent fluid leaking from the umbilicus of the baby. On examination, the umbilicus is inflamed, enlarged, and there is delayed healing of the cord stump. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Patent urachus

Explanation:

The scenario here points to the diagnosis of a patent urachus, and the preferred management is surgical excision.

Patent urachus is the non-descent of the bladder or failure of the epithelial-lined urachal canal to obliterate.

Clinical features:

  • Continuous or intermittent drainage of fluid from the umbilicus
  • Enlarged or edematous umbilicus
  • Delayed healing of the cord stump

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with non-muscle invasive bladder carcinoma is advised TURBT and BCG immunotherapy due to a high risk of recurrence. Which condition is not a contraindication for BCG therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Previous history of tuberculosis

 

Explanation:

A history of previous tuberculosis is not an absolute contraindication for using BCG in a bladder carcinoma patient. However, it may increase the risk of complications or decrease the treatment effectiveness.

 

Administration

  • Intravesical instillations: Administered postoperatively
  • Induction therapy: Weekly for 6 weeks
  • Maintenance therapy: Every 3 weeks for 3 years (variable intervals for 1-3 years)

Timing
  • BCG Therapy: Administered 6 weeks post-operatively, not immediately. (Option B)
  • Mitomycin C: Given immediately post-operatively.

Contraindications
  • Immunocompromised Patients: (Option A) Risk of BCG sepsis; requires a competent immune system.
  • Gross Hematuria: Risk of BCG entering circulation and causing systemic infection.
  • Total Urinary Incontinence (Option C): BCG is ineffective if it cannot remain in the bladder.
  • History of Previous BCG Sepsis or Hypersensitivity: Risk of severe reactions.

questions.text: During a radical cystectomy for bladder cancer in males, which of the following structures is typically spared and not removed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Testes

 

Explanation:

Structures Removed During Radical Cystectomy

Indications for Radical Cystectomy

Indications for Partial Cystectomy
  • Entire Bladder
  • Prostate  (Males) (Option B)
  • Seminal Vesicles (Option A) (Males)
  • Urethra (Option C)
  • Regional Lymph Nodes
  • Uterus and Ovaries (Females)
  • Invasive Bladder Cancer: Spread beyond the bladder lining
  • Non-Muscle Invasive Bladder Cancer: Recurrent and unresponsive to other treatments
  • Single Tumor: Confined to a single area of the bladder
  • Limited to Bladder Wall: Does not involve surrounding tissues or organs
  • Persistent or recurrent tumors in a localized area
  • High-Grade Tumors: Confined to a specific area, does not involve deeper layers or distant sites
  • Preservation of Bladder Function

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred initial therapy for a patient with carcinoma in situ (Tis) urinary bladder cancer after TURBT?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intravesical BCG therapy

 

Explanation:

  • Intravesical Bacille Calmette-Guérin (BCG) therapy is the preferred initial therapy for carcinoma in situ (Tis) urinary bladder cancer following TURBT.
  • BCG therapy is effective in reducing the risk of recurrence and progression in high-risk cases, including Tis, and is associated with improved long-term disease-specific survival compared to other therapies.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a tumor marker for urinary bladder cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Alpha-fetoprotein

 

Explanation:

Alpha-fetoprotein is not a tumour marker for urinary bladder cancer; it is primarily associated with liver cancer and germ cell tumours.
 

 

Tumor Markers

Helpful in diagnosis and for follow-up to assist the response of therapy and to detect recurrence

NMP22 (Nuclear Matrix Protein 22)

(Option B)

Measures levels of a protein released from bladder cancer cells into the urine.

BTA (Bladder Tumour Antigen)

(Option C)

Detects proteins associated with bladder cancer in the urine.

Hyaluronidase

(Option A)

Elevated levels of urinary HA and HAase have been observed in patients with bladder cancer.

HYAL-1 hyaluronidase is a potential prognostic marker for predicting muscle invasion and recurrence in non-muscle-invasive bladder cancer.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a bladder tumor invading the muscle layer is classified as which TNM stage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) T2

 

Explanation:

T2 lesions indicate invasion into the muscle layer of the bladder.
 

Primary Tumor Staging (TNM System)

The depth of invasion of the primary tumor in bladder cancer is a crucial prognostic factor for recurrence and progression.

Ta Lesions

(Option A)

Papillary (exophytic) tumors with a tendency to recur.

Tis Lesions

High-grade intraepithelial neoplasms (carcinoma in situ [CIS]) without invasion into subepithelial connective tissue.

T1 Lesions

(Option B)

Tumors invade the submucosa or lamina propria, typically high-grade.

T2 Lesions

(Option C)

Tumors invade muscle; cystectomy is standard therapy.

Presence of muscle invasion increases the likelihood of nodal and distant metastases.

T3 Lesions

(Option D)

Tumors extend beyond muscle into perivesical fat. Imaging (CT, MRI, PET) may help identify disease spread outside the bladder.

T4 Lesions

Tumors extend into adjacent organs.

T4a - invasion into the prostate, vagina, uterus, or bowel

T4b - tumors fixed to the abdominal wall, pelvic wall, or other organs.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with muscle-invasive bladder cancer is undergoing evaluation for metastasis. What is the most common lymphatic node involved in bladder cancer metastasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pelvic Nodes

 

Explanation:

Metastasis of Carcinoma Bladder:

 

Route of metastasis:
  • Direct extension into adjacent organs and/or the pelvic sidewall
  • Lymphatic spread
  • Hematogenous spread

Sites of Metastasis:
  • Lymph Nodes (69%): Pelvic (m/c) (Option C)> Retroperitoneal (Option C) > Intrathoracic (Option D)> Supraclavicular Nodes (Option A)
  • Bone (47%): Lytic lesions, sclerotic lesions or mixed lesions
  • Lungs (37%): Pulmonary nodules or consolidations
  • Liver (26%): Multiple Lesions or Solitary Lesions
  • Peritoneum (16%)
  • Other Metastatic Sites: Soft tissue, adrenal glands, brain
  • Tumors in a more advanced T category and those with atypical histologic features metastasize earlier.
  • Tumors with atypical histologic features also have a higher frequency of peritoneal metastasis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of smoking presents with frequent urination and microscopic hematuria. Cystoscopy reveals a flat, high-grade lesion confined to the bladder epithelium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Carcinoma in situ

 

Explanation:

Precursor lesions of carcinoma bladder:

 

Carcinoma in situ (CIS)
  • Epithelial lesions that have cytologic features of malignancy but are confined to the epithelium, with no basement membrane invasion.
  • Also called stage Tis bladder cancer or stage Tis transitional cell cancer (Tis, N0, M0).
  • High-grade, flat tumor on the bladder's inner lining, not invading deeper tissues.
  • Symptoms:
    • Dysuria
    • Nocturia
    • Frequent and urgent urination
    • Microscopic hematuria (Option B)
  • Diagnosis: Urine cytology, histopathology, immunostaining (CK 20, p53, CD44), and FISH for chromosome abnormalities.
  • Treatment: Intravesical BCG preferred

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) is brought with a few episodes of hematuria and bladder discomfort. Imaging shows a diverticulum near the ureteric orifice. Which of the following statements is most accurate based on the clinical scenario?

choices.text: Congenital diverticulum due to its location and UTIs.
Occurs secondary to high intravesical pressure.
Immediate surgery is needed regardless of symptoms.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Congenital diverticulum due to its location and UTIs.

 

Explanation:

Bladder diverticula can be congenital or acquired (secondary to intravesical bladder outlet obstruction).

 

Type

Congenital Diverticula

Acquired Diverticula

Cause

Develops due to herniation of bladder mucosa through congenital muscular defect between the intravesical ureter and roof of ureteral hiatus called Hutch diverticulum.

Secondary to bladder outlet obstruction, often due to prostatic issues in adult men.

Bladder characteristics

Thin-walled, typically located near the ureteric orifice, associated with vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) (Option A)
  • Thick-walled with trabeculations and multiple diverticula. (Option D)
  • High intravesical pressure causes bladder mucosa to protrude, forming saccules, which can become diverticula. (Option B)

Symptoms or complications

 
  • Haematuria (due to infection, stone or tumor) (30%)
  • Recurrent UTIs
  • Bladder stones
  • Urinary retention
  • Hydronephrosis
  • Bladder tumors (1%)

Diagnosis

  • Imaging (ultrasound, CT, MRI, cystogram) or cystoscopy.
  • Confirm bladder outlet obstruction with urodynamics if suspected.

Bladder diverticulum MRI:

Bladder diverticulum CT:

Cystogram with bladder diverticulum:

Cystoscopical view of bladder diverticulum:

Treatment

  • Congenital bladder diverticula is treated if symptomatic or for suspected malignancy. (Option C)
  • Open surgery or minimally invasive techniques for excision of diverticula; May require ureteric reimplantation based on diverticulum location.
  • Repair is done extravesical or through a combined extravesical or intravesical approach.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with severe abdominal pain and inability to urinate after a car accident. On examination, he has diffuse abdominal tenderness with guarding and rigidity. A cystogram reveals urine leakage into the peritoneal cavity. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Emergency laparotomy

 

Explanation:

  • In the above clinical scenario, the patient presents with signs and symptoms of intraperitoneal bladder rupture, which is a surgical emergency.
  • Therefore, emergency laparotomy is done immediately.

 

Intraperitoneal rupture

  • Involves a tear or injury to the peritoneum over the bladder, and urine leaks into the peritoneal cavity in males.
  • Causes: Often occurs in a fully distended bladder, usually due to trauma or injury.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Sudden, severe pain in the suprapubic region.
    • Signs of shock and syncope.
    • Diffuse abdominal pain with later features of peritonitis.
    • Abdominal distension.
    • Haematuria
    • Absence of desire to urinate.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Plain X-ray: May show ground glass appearance.
    • Peritoneal Tap: Used to collect urine from the abdominal cavity.
    • Cystography: Iodine dye is injected via a catheter to visualize bladder tears and the dye entry into the peritoneal cavity. The contrast outlines the bowel loops.
    • Ultrasound: To assess other abdominal injuries.
  • Treatment:
    • Emergency Laparotomy is required. (Option B).
    • Bladder tear is sutured with polylactic acid (vicryl) in two layers.
    • Peritoneal wash to clean out the peritoneal cavity.
    • Separate drainage for prevesical space and peritoneal cavity.
    • Administration of specific antibiotics to prevent sepsis.
    • Catheterization:
  • Malecot’s catheter is placed suprapubically.
  • Foley's catheter passed urethrally.
  • Complications:
    • Cystitis /and pyelonephritis.
    • Peritonitis.
    • Pelvic abscess.
    • Fistula formation (vesicovaginal or rectovesical).
    • Paralytic ileus.
    • Hemorrhage.
  • Prognosis: 100% mortality without surgery.

questions.text: A 48-year-old female presents with chronic pelvic pain, urinary urgency, and frequency. On cystoscopy, a characteristic bladder lesion with a small capacity and visible mucosal breaks is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Interstitial Cystitis with Hunner's Lesion

 

Explanation:

  • Interstitial Cystitis is a chronic bladder condition characterized by pelvic pain, urinary urgency, frequency, and a hallmark cystoscopic finding of Hunner’s lesions.
  • These are inflamed, ulcerative lesions on the bladder wall that are pathognomonic for this condition.
  • They often present with reduced bladder capacity and mucosal breaks, distinguishing them from other forms of cystitis and bladder pathologies.

questions.text:
Based on the images provided, where would each of the shown catheters be used?

Image 1:



Image 2:

choices.text: Image 1:Used for patients with acute urinary retention; Image 2:Used only in neurogenic bladder
Image 1: Used for patients with an enlarged prostate causing retention; Image 2: Used in cases of urethral stricture or trauma
Image 1: Used for short-term postoperative bladder drainage; Image 2:Used only when Foley's catheterization is contraindicated
Image 1: Used for patients with acute urinary retention; Image 2:Used for continuous bladder irrigation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Image 1: Used for patients with an enlarged prostate causing retention; Image 2: Used in cases of urethral stricture or trauma


 

Explanation:

Image 1 - The image given is of a Foley's catheter and is typically used for bladder drainage in patients with an enlarged prostate, which causes urinary retention.

Image 2 - This is an image of a Suprapubic Catheter (SPC) and is often chosen when there is a urethral stricture, trauma, or when urethral catheterization is not possible, but it is not the ONLY indication of using SPC

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident with a pelvic fracture and gross hematuria. The CT cystogram showed the following characteristic findings. Which of the following statements regarding the diagnosis of this patient is incorrect?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Retrograde cystography demonstrates extravasation of contrast limited to the perivesical space.
Catheter drainage for 10-14 days is the treatment of choice for uncomplicated cases.
Immediate surgical repair in cases of bladder neck injury.
Both urethral and suprapubic catheters are recommended in all cases.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Both urethral and suprapubic catheters are recommended in all cases.

 

Explanation:

  • The contrast extravasation seen on CT cystography is confined to the perivesical space, giving a characteristic flame-shaped appearance, which is seen in Extraperitoneal bladder rupture.
  • While the use of both urethral and suprapubic catheters might be considered in complex cases, it is not universally recommended.
  • Routine use of both types of catheters can increase morbidity and delay hospital discharge.
  • The American Urological Association (AUA) guidelines recommend against the routine placement of a suprapubic catheter following bladder injury repair.

 

Flame sign in Extraperitoneal bladder rupture :

Retrograde cystography is the imaging modality of choice for diagnosing bladder ruptures, including extraperitoneal injuries.(Option A)

  • Extravasation of contrast limited to the perivesical space is a key finding that helps differentiate extraperitoneal from intraperitoneal ruptures, where contrast would outline bowel loops.

 

Conservative management with catheter drainage for 10-14 days is the standard treatment for uncomplicated extraperitoneal bladder injuries, especially when associated with pelvic fractures. (Option B)

  • This approach allows time for the injury to heal without surgical intervention.

 

Immediate surgical repair is indeed indicated in cases where there are complicating factors like intravesical bone spicules, bladder neck injuries, or associated vaginal or rectal lacerations. (Option C)

  • These complications increase the risk of fistula formation, abscess, and incontinence, warranting prompt surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with recurrent UTIs and a history of chronic immunosuppression after a renal transplant presents with non-tender abdominal nodules. The biopsy shows histiocytes with basophilic inclusions staining positive for PAS and von Kossa stains. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: Commonly associated with Gram-negative bacteria like E. coli
Characteristic histological feature is Langhans giant cells
Usually self-limiting and resolves without treatment

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Commonly associated with Gram-negative bacteria like E. coli

Explanation:

  • Malakoplakia is a rare inflammatory condition often seen in immunocompromised patients, such as those with chronic immunosuppression following organ transplants.
  • It is commonly associated with Gram-negative bacteria, particularly Escherichia coli.
  • The histological hallmark of malakoplakia is the presence of von Hansemann cells (large, foamy histiocytes) and Michaelis-Gutmann bodies (PAS-positive, basophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions that also stain with von Kossa and Perl’s stains).
  • Treatment- Antibiotics (fluoroquinolones, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole), possible surgical excision

Michaelis-Gutmann bodies:

questions.text: A 45-year-old male tourist from rural Egypt presents with recurrent hematuria and lower abdominal pain. A pelvic radiograph shows a circular calcification resembling a fetal head in the pelvis with associated faint calcification of the distal right ureter. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate next step?

choices.text: Chronic schistosomiasis; obtain urine microscopy for ova
Pelvic tuberculosis; order interferon-gamma release assay
Calcified bladder tumor; schedule CT urography

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chronic schistosomiasis; obtain urine microscopy for ova

 

Explanation:

  • The "fetal head in pelvis" appearance on the pelvic radiograph is pathognomonic for chronic urinary schistosomiasis.
  • Pelvic radiograph shows the classic appearance of the calcified bladder, which resembles a fetal head in the pelvis, with associated faint calcification of the distal right ureter.
  • The patient's origin from rural Egypt, an endemic area for Schistosoma haematobium, further supports this diagnosis.
  • Urine microscopy for ova remains the definitive diagnostic test for schistosomiasis.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy from a rural area presents with suprapubic pain, increased urinary frequency, and occasional hematuria, with no incontinence or systemic symptoms. He appears thin, has normal external genitalia, and has no significant medical history. Imaging shows multiple small, smooth bladder stones. What is the most likely cause?

choices.text: Bladder outlet obstruction leading to urinary stasis
Foreign body presence in the bladder

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Nutritional deficiency

Explanation:

  • Primary bladder stones are commonly seen in children, often in developing regions, and are related to dietary deficiencies, particularly in vitamins A and B6, magnesium, and an imbalanced protein-carbohydrate ratio.

  • This patient’s appearance, history, and lack of other contributory factors point towards a nutritional deficiency as the cause of his primary bladder stone.

Aetiology of Bladder Stones

Type

Primary Bladder Stones

Secondary Bladder Stones

Causes

Nutritional deficiency (Vitamins A, B6, magnesium, protein-carbohydrate imbalance) (Option C)

Bladder outlet obstruction, infection, foreign body presence (Option A, B, D)

Common Composition

Ammonium urate, calcium oxalate

Uric acid, struvite (infection-related)

Common Population

Children in developing countries

Adults with urinary tract dysfunction or infection

Clinical Presentation

May be asymptomatic or present with dysuria, hematuria

Hematuria, dysuria, frequency and urgency,

questions.text: Which of the following statements about ectopia vesicae is correct?

choices.text: More common in females than males
Increased risk of urinary bladder adenocarcinoma
Resolves on its own without surgery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Increased risk of urinary bladder adenocarcinoma

 

Explanation:

Ectopia vesicae, also known as bladder exstrophy, is associated with an increased risk of developing urinary bladder adenocarcinoma due to chronic irritation and exposure of the bladder's internal lining.

Ectopia vesicae:

  • It is a rare congenital defect where the urinary bladder is exposed outside the abdomen due to a failure to develop the lower abdominal wall.
  • M/c in males. (Option A ruled out)
  • Continuous leakage of urine due to the inability to close the bladder outlet. Vesicoureteral reflux, possible renal anomalies like renal dysplasia or hydronephrosis. (Option B ruled out)
  • Surgical Management of Ectopia Vesicae: (Option D ruled out)
    • Staged Reconstruction with B/L pelvic osteotomies to facilitate abdominal wall closure and reduce tension in the neonatal period.
    • Epispadias repair and reconstruction of the urethra and external genitalia at 6-12 months of age.
    • Bladder Neck Reconstruction (BNR) to treat VUR at 5-7 yrs.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with diabetes and Parkinson’s disease presents with a 6-month history of difficulty urinating, incomplete bladder emptying, and frequent nighttime urination. A post-void residual volume test shows significant urine retention. Which of the following conditions is least likely the primary cause of his chronic urinary retention?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Overactive Bladder

 

Explanation:

  • Overactive Bladder is associated with frequent urination and urgency, not with chronic urinary retention.
  • The other conditions listed - Parkinson's disease, diabetic neuropathy, and BPH can directly lead to chronic urinary retention due to their impact on bladder function or outlet obstruction.
